comments.commentBody:
The Times should do a comparison of the CPC and the Ryan plans. The American people deserve choices. Do we continue with trickle-down and austerity policies, where we see the gap between the wealthy and everyone else is growing wider and wider, or do we put America back to work by reducing speculation and stimulating the economy?

The CPC’s anti-austerity budget achieves deficit reduction mostly from new revenue generated by increasing demand in the overall economy. After WWII, the country made investments to grow the economy: the interstate highway system, investments in housing, conversion of military plants, the GI Bill, the NASA program. By 1978, we reduced the debt from over 120 percent of GDP to under 30 percent. That is how the country paid off its debt while, at the same time, improving the standard of living for workers.

Pope Francis understands economics better than most conservatives. He rightly points out that voodoo economics has been a failure:

“Some people continue to defend trickle-down theories which assume that economic growth, encouraged by a free market, will inevitably succeed in bringing about greater justice and inclusiveness in the world. This opinion, which has never been confirmed by the facts, expresses a crude and naïve trust in the goodness of those wielding economic power and in the sacralized workings of the prevailing economic system. Meanwhile, the excluded are still waiting.”
I think we also go back to re-inhabit a more innocent and open way of looking at the world.  (I suspect when we fail at the openness part, we get stuck in a regression.)

This is a beautiful piece of writing. The journey of revisiting the past, extracting its lessons, and using it to liberate and build a better future is a key aspect of ripening into maturity. In my judgment, the key is transcending the limitations of the past, which can require examination and reinterpretation of painful events.

But digging down and reinterpreting is not the only part of this process. An essential component is finding the hope, resilience and courage to move forward. The creativity embodied in the TED talks encourages others to take leaps.

I think what the West, and the public interest overall wants is, rule by law (with the assumption that the law balances orderliness, fairness and liberty and a variety of other important principles) on an international level.

When George Bush the Superior announced "a new world order" in response to Saddam's invasion of Kuwait, he was talking about a rule of law regarding and checking naked aggression.

Ironically, Bush the Inferior threw out the notion when he invaded Iraq. The first time a full franchised democracy had done so (begging the question is the United States a democracy?).

I've mentioned many times, we still don't know if we have survived Bush the Inferior, and might not for another 75 years. Certainly the global economy is still suffering from his xfer of $13 trillion from the demand side of the economy (the 99%) to the supply side (the 1%) - (most of which he completed in his first 4 years while he had only a negative mandate - can you spell c.o.u.p.?).

In this case Bush the inferiors actions in Iraq thoroughly destroy our ability to impose moral authority rule of law over Russia and has hobbled the world we live in in its attempts at trying to create and impose rule by law upon the behavior of states and their governments.

The enormity of this is hard to over estimate. It's not just invasions we want international law to govern. There is also genocide, cruelty, torture, use of chemical weapons, nuclear materials, the list goes on and on.

Thanks George.
These regulations will do nothing to solve the problem. How does not selling a 100-year-old chess piece prevent the extinction of elephants? If we're serous about the problem, we'll take real action.
Let's hope that this decision will be appealed and reversed.  Voter suppression undermines American democracy and needs to be stamped out.

Someone else who didn't read the article. The sale of new ivory is illegal. We're talking about antiques and banning their sale won't save a single elephant. I'd gladly burn the few ivory items here if it would help. But it won't.

We've been waiting for so long for some action like this that might help curb the ivory trade that I for one feel that those who have collected are getting what they should have long expected. A reverse in their ivory fortunes. If this is what it takes to keep people like them from buying more and more ivory then I say GREAT. The slaughter of elephants has been nothing less than horrific and everything, everything needs to be done to help preserve this wonderful, amazing, social, intelligent species. Much more needs to be done. So let the chips among collectors and musicians fall where they may. If they cannot travel with their ivory, that's tough. But if it helps protect elephants when other measures were not working, I don't care.
Yet it is legal to trade mammoth ivory, a non-renewable resource because all the mammoths were killed long ago, probably by people.
Absolutely true.  But the keys on an antique piano do absolutely nothing to contribute to today's trade in ivory.
How will banning ivory trade in the U.S. affect the Chinese imports of ivory?
I hope that ivory becomes as worthless as the soulless ghouls crying in their closets. Shame on them.

Steinway has not used real ivory for quite some time on their piano keys, using a synthetic material that works just as well. So the piano market is not creating demand for new ivory. This regulation just sweeps up all the people who have bought these things that were designed to last such as handmade violins, bows, pianos etc that have great value by their own intrinsic value, not the ivory which was just standard decorative material in the days when these instruments were made. My piano was made in the 1950's and the ivory on it was the least of my considerations.

These instruments are not just collectors items, they are the livelihood of talented people who put in hours and hours honing their craft. So now customs impounds these indiscriminately should someone have the fortune to be offered work in another country having nothing to do with the instruments being sold?

We have a huge swath of undereducated humanity that can't see anything wrong with the concept of a huge government able to right all the wrongs and weaknesses of humanity - if only we made it big enough. These people never heard of all the totalitarian and authoritarian nations that tried this, all of them failing - and most of them gleefully murdering their own citizens whenever some tyrant thinks it necessary.

Zero tolerance rules in schools are the same sort of thing. Actual leadership demands that reasonable exeptions and actual decisions on a per-case basis be made. Poachers should be getting caught every time on the age of drones with cameras - especially night-vision equipment. Maybe some day....

As long as ivory is financially valuable, people will poach elephants to get it.

The proper solution is not simply to ban the sale of ivory, but to actively destroy it, everywhere it is found. Immediately.

Given our 100% track record of failure with prohibition of various substances you would have thought that the Federal government would finally learn the futility of such measures.  Here they have banned the sale or transport of old ivory with no indication that such sales contribute one whit to the endangerment of living elephants.  No doubt what this ban will achieve is an increase in the value of black market ivory and an increase in the slaughter of elephants.  The glee of the pudding headed preservationists here in the comments section shows that feelings are still more important to many of our fellow citizens than logic and results are.  Let's hope that cooler heads prevail.

Why include walrus tusk which is indigenous to North American waters and hunted in limited quantity by Inuit people? Is this a case where it is just easier for the U. S. Dep't of Interior to ban anything that looks like elephant ivory, rather than take the time and trouble to distinguish the difference? Will pyroxene plastics be next?

With terrorist threats, a sputtering economy and international crises, don't these folks have anything better to do?
Completely agree with your assessment. This isn't about money. It's about the survival of an entire species. That in and of itself is priceless, and beyond deliberation.

"Tastes and markets change."

The article is about government regulation, not "Tastes and markets", so your buggy whip example is completely irrelevant.

BTW, coal mining stocks are still actively traded. For example:
http://quotes.wsj.com/JRCC
In addition, how can the government prove that the item was not made from an elephants tusk that just died from natural causes rather than being poached.

My question is. How do you actually know if it's old or new ivory? Where does there exist a test to make that determination? There will always be those who participate in the slaughter of elephants for their tusks who will attempt to forge a "antiquated" look to sell their ill gained product.  And based on anything that says otherwise, the best thing is to ban all of it.

No ones is saying people want to slaughter elephants, but just be able to sell their or buy products that were once legal.

So if Vince Gill ever decided to sell one of his guitars, it may be illegal.

It is pretty easy to tell the difference between old and new ivory and I cannot see how criminalizing the trade in pieces that are pre-ban will save a single elephant today. Stunningly beautiful pieces of art that are hundreds of years old will become valueless, and those who have them will lose the money they invested. They are not all in the 1% and these pieces were/are contributing to retirement. The problem is not with the ban, it's the retroactive nature of it.
This ban won't stop poaching because the world is a lot bigger than the USA, and the biggest market for ivory is in China. It's an easy no-brainer to say "Stop slaughtering noble elephants!" but I wonder how many of these people that decry the slaughter of elephants eat meat? That's heartless slaughter on a daily scale that dwarfs that of the elephant, and they're complicit in that suffering every time they eat a burger or chicken sandwich.

A measure that has no relationship to the purpose sought to be achieved can be as drastic as all get out but that doesn't make it sensible.  Its like a baby's drastic measure of holding its breath until it gets its way.  It's great to ban any further use of ivory - whether for repair, manufacture - whatever - whether drastic or not, those strategies make sense.  Getting hysterical about musical instruments manufactured 60 years ago (documented, no less), which have some ivory components does not.

Is it really a matter of cost? I doubt it. Some pilots are against tracking of their flight paths and regularly turn off their transponders.

The quote in the article is relevant:
"Industry officials say pilots need to be able to turn off any transmission system in case it starts a fire."

This is clearly just an excuse. The transponder could easily be located outside the cockpit where it could catch fire or not without interfering with the pilot's work any more than any other mishap.

Finding a plane after it goes down, especially if due to intentional intervention, in no way "protects you", it doesn't stop the malfunction or attack, but just simplifies the follow up process.    If you've used a GPS navigation system you will also know from experience that on occasion it tells you things that are wrong or routes that don't exist.  Another piece in today's NYT speaks well to our over reliance on our belief that we have it all figured out.

Chris Brown - inside or outside of the cockpit (and most in large planes they are in large electronic bays below floor level already, not physically in the cockpit, just the switches) totally misses the reality of what electrical fires in flight can do and how they spread.  Any electrical fire anywhere on a plane in flight surely will "interfere" with the pilots work and can't be ignored just because it is happening some where other than the flight deck.

"But for a variety of reasons, mostly involving cost and how infrequently planes crash, neither the airlines nor their regulators adopted them." I seriously hope this tragedy rings the alarm so that the extra measures of tracking will be adopted soon. Most of us, I believe, are willing to pay more for safety of life.
I suspect that it costs much, much more money to lose an airliner...and its passengers.

“It’s ironic that we have this technology so passengers can pay to watch reruns of ‘Charlie’s Angels,’ but that we still have to make the safety case for their use,” Mr. Mann said.
The key word in that quote is "pay." The airlines make money on the reruns, but it costs money to track an airliner.
